The Fair Value of Data Under Heterogeneous Privacy
Constraints in Federated Learning

Justin S. Kang justin_kang@berkeley.edu
UC Berkeley Ramtin Pedarsani ramtin@ece.ucsb.edu
UC Santa Barbara Kannan Ramchandran kannanr@berkeley.edu
UC Berkeley
Abstract

Modern data aggregation often involves a platform collecting data from a network of users with various privacy options. Platforms must solve the problem of how to allocate incentives to users to convince them to share their data. This paper puts forth an idea for a fair amount to compensate users for their data at a given privacy level based on an axiomatic definition of fairness, along the lines of the celebrated Shapley value. To the best of our knowledge, these are the first fairness concepts for data that explicitly consider privacy constraints. We also formulate a heterogeneous federated learning problem for the platform with privacy level options for users. By studying this problem, we investigate the amount of compensation users receive under fair allocations with different privacy levels, amounts of data, and degrees of heterogeneity. We also discuss what happens when the platform is forced to design fair incentives. Under certain conditions we find that when privacy sensitivity is low, the platform will set incentives to ensure that it collects all the data with the lowest privacy options. When the privacy sensitivity is above a given threshold, the platform will provide no incentives to users. Between these two extremes, the platform will set the incentives so some fraction of the users chooses the higher privacy option and the others chooses the lower privacy option.

1 Introduction

From media to healthcare to transportation, the vast amount of data generated by people every day has solved difficult problems across many domains. Nearly all machine learning algorithms, including those based on deep learning rely heavily on data and many of the largest companies to ever exist center their business around this precious resource of data. This includes directly selling access to data to others for profit, selling targeted advertisements based on data, or by exploiting data through data-driven engineering, to better develop and market products. Simultaneously, as users become more privacy conscious, online platforms are increasingly providing privacy level options for users. Platforms may provide incentives to users to influence their privacy decisions. This manuscript investigates how platforms can fairly compensate users for their data contribution at a given privacy level. Consider a platform offering geo-location services with three privacy level options:

  1. i)

    Users send no data to the platform — all data processing is local and private.

  2. ii)

    An intermediate option with federated learning (FL) for privacy. Data remains with the users, but the platform can ask for gradients with respect to a particular loss function.

  3. iii)

    A non-private option, where all user data is stored and owned by the platform.

If users choose option (i), the platform does not stand to gain from using that data in other tasks. If the user chooses (ii), the platform is better off, but still has limited access to the data via FL and may not be able to fully leverage its potential. Therefore, the platform wants to incentivize users to choose option (iii). This may be done by providing services, discounts or money to users that choose this option. Effectively, by choosing an option, users are informally selling (or not selling) their data to platforms. Due to the lack of a formal exchange, it can be difficult to understand if this sale of user data is fair. Are platforms making the cost of choosing private options like (i) or (ii) too high? Is the value of data much higher than the platform is paying?

A major shortcoming of the current understanding of data value is that it often fails to explicitly consider a critical factor in an individual’s decision to share data—privacy. This work puts forth two rigorous notions of the fair value of data in Section 3 that explicitly include privacy and make use of the axiomatic framework of the Shapley value from game theory (Shapley, 1952).

Compelled by the importance of data in our modern economy and a growing social concern about privacy, this paper presents frameworks for quantifying the fair value of private data. Specifically, we consider a setting where users are willing to provide their data to a platform in exchange for some sort of payment and under some privacy guarantees depending on their level of privacy requirements. The platform is responsible for running the private learning algorithm on the gathered data and making the fair payments with the objective of maximizing its utility including statistical accuracy and total amount of payments. Our goal is to understand fair mechanisms for this procedure as depicted in Fig. 1.

1.1 Related Work

Economics

With the widespread use of the internet, interactions involving those that have data and those that want it have become an important area of study (Balazinska et al., 2011), and a practical necessity (Spiekermann et al., 2015b). Among these interactions, the economics of data from privacy conscious users has received significant attention in Acquisti et al. (2016) and Wieringa et al. (2021). The economic and social implications of privacy and data markets are considered in Spiekermann et al. (2015a). In Acemoglu et al. (2019) the impact of data externalities is investigated. The leakage of data leading to the suppression of its market value is considered.

Privacy

Currently, popular forms of privacy include federated learning (Kairouz et al., 2021) and differential privacy (DP) (Dwork, 2008; Bun & Steinke, 2016) either independently or in conjunction with one another. Our work uses a flexible framework that allows for a rage of different privacy models to be considered.

Optimal Data Acquisition

One line of literature studies data acquisition, where platforms attempt to collect data from privacy conscious users. Ghosh & Ligett (2013) consider the case of uniform privacy guarantees (homogeneous DP), where users have unique minimum privacy constraints, focusing on characterizing equilibria. Ghosh & Roth (2011) allows for heterogeneous DP guarantees with the goal to design a dominant strategy truthful mechanism to acquire data and estimate the sum of users’ binary data. In Fallah et al. (2022) the authors consider an optimal data acquisition problem in the context of private mean estimation in two different local and central heterogeneous DP settings. It is assumed that players care about both the estimation error of the common estimator generated by the platform and any payments made to them by the platform in their decision making. By assuming linear privacy sensitivity represented by scalars and drawn from a distribution, they devise a mechanism for computing the near-Bayes optimal privacy levels to provide to the players. Cummings et al. (2023) focuses on the central setting, under both the linear privacy sensitivity and the privacy constraints model, offering insights into the optimal solution. Hu & Gong (2020) goes beyond linear estimation to consider FL, where each user has a unique privacy sensitivity function parameterized by a scalar variable. Users choose their privacy level, and the platform pays them via a proportional scheme. For linear privacy sensitivity functions, an efficient way to compute the Nash equilibrium is derived. Roth & Schoenebeck (2012); Chen et al. (2018); Chen & Zheng (2019) also follow Ghosh & Roth (2011) and design randomized mechanisms that use user data with a probability that depends on their reported privacy sensitivity value.

Fairness

In Jia et al. (2019), Ghorbani & Zou (2019) and Ghorbani et al. (2020) a framework for determining the fair value of data is proposed. These works extend the foundational principles of the Shapley value (Shapley, 1952), which was originally proposed as a concept for utility division in coalitional games to the setting of data. Our work takes this idea further and explicitly includes privacy in the definition of the fair value of data, ultimately allowing us to consider private data acquisition in the context of fairness constraints. Finally, we note that we consider the concept of fairness in data valuation, not algorithmic fairness, which relates to the systematic failure of machine learning systems to account for data imbalances.

1.2 Main Contributions

  • •

    We present an axiomatic notion of fairness that is inclusive of the platforms and the users in Theorem 1. The utility to be awarded to each user and the platform is uniquely determined, providing a useful benchmark for comparison.

  • •

    In the realistic scenario that fairness is considered between users, Theorem 2 defines a notion of fairness based on axioms, but only places restriction on relative amounts distributed to the players. This creates an opportunity for the platform to optimize utility under fairness constraints.

  • •

    Section 4 contains an example inspired by online platform advertisement to heterogeneous users. We use our framework to fairly allocate payments, noticing how those payments differ among different types of users, and how payments change as the degree of heterogeneity increases or decreases. We numerically investigate the mechanism design problem under this example and see how heterogeneity impacts the optimal behavior of the platform.

  • •

    Finally, Section 5 explores the platform mechanism design problem. In Theorem 3 we establish that there are three distinct regimes in which the platform’s optimal behavior differs depending on the common privacy sensitivity of the users. While existing literature has investigated how a platform should design incentives for users to optimize its utility, this is the first work to consider fairness constraints on the platform. When privacy sensitivity is low, the platform will set incentives to ensure that it collects all the data with the lowest privacy options. When the privacy sensitivity is above a given threshold, the platform will provide no incentives to users. Between these two extremes, the platform will set the incentives so some fraction of the users chooses the higher privacy option and the remaining chooses the lower privacy option.

2 PROBLEM SETTING

2.1 Privacy Levels and Utility Functions

Definition 1.

A heterogeneous privacy framework on the space of random function A:𝒳N→𝒴:𝐴→superscript𝒳𝑁𝒴A:\mathcal{X}^{N}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} is:

  1. 1.

    A set of privacy levels ℰ⊆ℝ≥0∪{∞}ℰsubscriptℝabsent0\mathcal{E}\subseteq\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\cup\{\infty\}, representing the amount of privacy of each user. We use ρ𝜌\rho to represent an element of ℰℰ\mathcal{E} in the general case and ϵitalic-ϵ{\epsilon} when the privacy levels are referring to DP parameters (defined below).

  2. 2.

    A constraint set 𝒜​(𝝆)⊆{A:𝒳N→𝒴}𝒜𝝆conditional-set𝐴→superscript𝒳𝑁𝒴\mathcal{A}(\bm{\rho})\subseteq\{A:\mathcal{X}^{N}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}\}, representing the set of random functions that respect the privacy levels ρi∈ℰsubscript𝜌𝑖ℰ\rho_{i}\in\mathcal{E} for all i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N]. If a function A∈𝒜​(𝝆)𝐴𝒜𝝆A\in\mathcal{A}(\bm{\rho}) then we call it a 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}-private algorithm.

We maintain this general notion of privacy framework because different notions of privacy can be useful in different situations. For example, the lack of rigor associated with notions such as FL, may make it unsuitable for high security applications, but it may be very useful in protecting users against data breaches on servers, by keeping their data local. One popular choice with rigorous guarantees is DP:

Definition 2.

Pure heterogeneous ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP, is a heterogeneous privacy framework with ℰ=ℝ≥0∪{∞}ℰsubscriptℝabsent0\mathcal{E}=\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\cup\{\infty\} and the constraint set 𝒜​(ϵ)={A:Pr​(A​(𝐱)∈S)≤eϵi​Pr​(A​(𝐱′)∈S)}𝒜bold-italic-ϵconditional-set𝐴Pr𝐴𝐱𝑆superscript𝑒subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖Pr𝐴superscript𝐱′𝑆\mathcal{A}(\bm{\epsilon})=\{A:\mathrm{Pr}(A(\mathbf{x})\in S)\leq e^{{\epsilon}_{i}}\mathrm{Pr}(A(\mathbf{x}^{\prime})\in S)\} for all measurable sets S𝑆S.

Henceforth we will use the symbol ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon} to represent privacy level when we are specifically referring to DP as our privacy framework, but if we are referring to a general privacy level, we will use 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}. Fig. 2, depicts another heterogeneous privacy framework. ρi=0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}=0 means the user will keep their data fully private, ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 is an intermediate privacy option where user data is securely aggregated with other users before it is sent to the platform, which obfuscates it from the platform. Finally, if ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2, the users send a sufficient statistic for their data to the platform.

The platform applies an 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}-private algorithm A𝝆:𝒳N↦𝒴:subscript𝐴𝝆maps-tosuperscript𝒳𝑁𝒴A_{\bm{\rho}}:\mathcal{X}^{N}\mapsto\mathcal{Y} to process the data, providing privacy level ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} to data xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. The output of the algorithm y=A𝝆​(𝐱)𝑦subscript𝐴𝝆𝐱y=A_{\bm{\rho}}(\mathbf{x}) is used by the platform to derive utility U𝑈U, which depends on the privacy level 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}.

For example, if the platform is estimating the mean of a population, the utility could depend on the mean square error of the private estimator.

Differences from prior work

This formulation differs from the literature of optimal data acquisition (i.e., Fallah et al. (2022)), where privacy sensitivity is reported by users, and the platform chooses privacy levels ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} based on this sensitivity. Privacy sensitivity is the cost that a user experiences by choosing a particular privacy level. Their formulation allows for a relatively straightforward application of notions like incentive compatibility and individual rationality from mechanism design theory. In this work, we instead emphasize that users choose a privacy level, rather than report a somewhat nebulously defined privacy sensitivity. Despite this difference, the notions of fairness described in the following section can be applied more broadly.

2.2 The Data Acquisition Problem

The platform generates transferable and divisible utility U​(𝝆)𝑈𝝆U(\bm{\rho}) from the user data. In exchange, distributes a portion of the utility ti​(ρi;𝝆−i)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}) to user i𝑖i, where 𝝆−isubscript𝝆𝑖\bm{\rho}_{-i} denotes the vector of privacy levels 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho} with the i𝑖ith coordinate deleted. These incentives motivate users to lower their privacy level, but each user will also have some sensitivity to their data being shared, modelled by a sensitivity function ci:ℰ→[0,∞):subscript𝑐𝑖→ℰ0c_{i}:\mathcal{E}\rightarrow[0,\infty), ci​(0)=0subscript𝑐𝑖00c_{i}(0)=0. The behavior of users can be modelled with the help of a utility function:

ui​(𝝆)=ti​(ρi,𝝆−i)−ci​(ρi).subscript𝑢𝑖𝝆subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖u_{i}(\bm{\rho})=t_{i}(\rho_{i},\bm{\rho}_{-i})-c_{i}(\rho_{i}). (1)

The payment to user i𝑖i will tend to increase with a lower privacy level, as the platform can better exploit the data, but their sensitivity cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} will increase with ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}, creating a trade-off. By specifying ti​(ρi;𝝆−i)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}), the platform effectively creates a game among the users. This situation is depicted in Fig. 3. Each user’s action is the level of privacy that they request for the data they share. Users (players) select their privacy level ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} by considering their utility function uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} and the potential actions of the other players. The platform’s goal is to design the payments ti​(ρi;𝝆−i)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}) that maximize its net utility U​(𝝆)−𝟙T​𝐭​(𝝆)𝑈𝝆superscript1𝑇𝐭𝝆U(\bm{\rho})-\mathds{1}^{T}\mathbf{t}(\bm{\rho}). One way to formulate this problem is to consider maximizing this difference at equilibrium points: {maxi}<b > t(⋅), ρ U(ρ) - 1^T t(ρ) \addConstraint ρ∈NE(t). NE​(𝐭)NE𝐭\text{NE}(\mathbf{t}) denotes the set of NE strategies induced by the payment function 𝐭𝐭\mathbf{t}, which is the vector with payment function tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i} at index i𝑖i. Recall that the NE is a stable state such that no user gains by unilaterally changing their strategy. Depending on the circumstances, we may also want to consider equilibrium points in mixed strategies (distributions) over the privacy space. This could make sense if we expect users to continually interact with the platform, making a different choice each time, such that users ultimately converge to their long-run average payoff. In such cases, we can formulate the problem for the platform as: {maxi}<b > t(⋅), P U(P) - 1^T t(P) \addConstraint P ∈NE(t). where we have used the shorthand f​(𝒫)=𝔼𝝆∼𝒫​[f​(𝝆)]𝑓𝒫subscript𝔼similar-to𝝆𝒫delimited-[]𝑓𝝆f(\mathcal{P})=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\rho}\sim\mathcal{P}}\left[f(\bm{\rho})\right] and 𝒫𝒫\mathcal{P} represents a distribution over the privacy space ℰℰ\mathcal{E}. Note that in both equation 1 and equation 1 restrictions must be placed on 𝐭𝐭\mathbf{t}, otherwise it can be made arbitrarily negative. Individual rationality is a common condition in mechanism design that says that a user can be made no worse off by participation. In Section 5, we consider a fairness constraint.

2.3 Model Limitations

Known sensitivity functions

To solve equation 1, the platform requires the privacy sensitivity cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} of each user, and our solution in Section 5 depends on this information. This can be justified when platforms interact with businesses. For example, an AI heath platform may interact with insurance companies and hospitals and can invest significant resources into studying each of its partners. Another example is advertisement platforms and sellers. Another justification is that the privacy sensitivity cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} is learned by the platforms over time, and we are operating in a regime where the estimates of cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} have converged. An interesting future direction could be investigating this learning problem.

Data-correlated sensitivity

In Section 5 we treat the sensitivity function cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} as fixed and known, but a practical concern is that cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} may depends on the data xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. Say xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} is biological data pertaining to a disease. Those users with the diseases may have higher cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}. Without taking this into account, the collected data will be biased. If our utility function is greatly increased by those users who do have the disease though, they may receive far more payment, compensating for this correlation. We leave a investigation of data-correlated sensitivity and fairness to future work.

Known transferable and divisible utility

Solving equation 1 also requires knowledge of the utility function. In some cases, the platform may dictate the utility entirely on its own, perhaps to value a diverse set of users. In other cases, like in the estimation setting of Example 3.2, it may represent a more concrete metric, like a risk function that is easily computed. In some cases, however, the utility function may not be easily computed. For example, it may depend on the revenue of a company’s product, or the downstream performance of a deep network. We also note that ti​(ρi;𝝆−i)subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖t_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}) may not represent a monetary transfer. Individuals are often compensated for data via discounts or access to services. A shortcoming of our model is that we assume a divisible and transferable utility, which may fail to capture these nuances of compensation.

Informed and Strategic Users

We also assume that users can compute and play their equilibrium strategy, which is a standard assumption in game theory. Practically this also means that the platform must be transparent about the incentives, fully publishing this information to the users.

3 Axiomatic Fairness with Privacy

What is a fair way to distribute incentives? One approach is to view the users and platforms as a coalition jointly generating utility. Following an axiomatic approach to fairness, the celebrated Shapley value (Shapley, 1952) describes how to fairly divide utility among a coalition. In this section, we take a similar approach to defining fairness. This coalitional perspective is not a complete characterization of the complex dynamics between users and platforms, but we argue that it is still a useful one. One of the benefits of this concept of fairness is that it deals with intrinsic value (i.e., how much of the utility comes from the data). This is in contrast to the market value that users are willing to sell for (potentially depressed). This information is particularly useful to economists, regulators, and investors, who are interested in characterizing the value of data as capital for the purposes of analysis, taxation, and investment respectively.

3.1 Platform as a Coalition Member

We define a coalition of users and a platform as a collection of s𝑠s users, with 0≤s≤N0𝑠𝑁0\leq s\leq N and up to 111 platform. Let z∈{0,1}𝑧01z\in\{0,1\} represent the action of the platform. Let z=1𝑧1z=1 when the platform chooses to join the coalition, and z=0𝑧0z=0 otherwise. Let U​(𝝆)𝑈𝝆U(\bm{\rho}) be as defined in Section 2. We augment the utility to take into account that the utility is zero if the platform does not participate, and define 𝝆Ssubscript𝝆𝑆\bm{\rho}_{S} as follows:

Theorem 1.

Let ϕp​(z,ϵ)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝𝑧bold-ϵ\phi_{p}(z,\bm{\epsilon}) and ϕi​(z,ϵ)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑧bold-ϵ\phi_{i}(z,\bm{\epsilon}) satisfying axioms (A.i-iii) represent the portion of total utility awarded to the platform and each user i𝑖i from utility U​(z,ϵ)𝑈𝑧bold-ϵU(z,\bm{\epsilon}). Then they are unique and take the form:

ϕp​(z,𝝆)=1N+1​∑S⊆[N]1(N|S|)​U​(z,𝝆S),subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝𝑧𝝆1𝑁1subscript𝑆delimited-[]𝑁1binomial𝑁𝑆𝑈𝑧subscript𝝆𝑆\phi_{p}(z,\bm{\rho})=\frac{1}{N+1}\sum_{S\subseteq[N]}\frac{1}{\binom{N}{\left\lvert{S}\right\rvert}}U(z,\bm{\rho}_{S}), (3)
ϕi​(z,𝝆)=1N+1​∑S⊆[N]\{i}1(N|S|+1)​(U​(z,𝝆S∪{i})−U​(z,𝝆S)).subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑧𝝆1𝑁1subscript𝑆\delimited-[]𝑁𝑖1binomial𝑁𝑆1𝑈𝑧subscript𝝆𝑆𝑖𝑈𝑧subscript𝝆𝑆\phi_{i}(z,\bm{\rho})=\frac{1}{N+1}\sum_{S\subseteq[N]\backslash\{i\}}\frac{1}{\binom{N}{\left\lvert{S}\right\rvert+1}}\left(U(z,\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{i\}})-U(z,\bm{\rho}_{S})\right). (4)

Theorem 1 is proved in Appendix B.2, and resembles the classic Shapley value result (Shapley, 1952).

3.2 Fairness Among Users

Though we can view the interactions between the platform and the users as a coalition, due to the asymmetry that exists between the platform and the users, it also makes sense to discuss fairness among the users alone. In this case, we can consider an analogous set of axioms that involve only the users.

  1. B.i)

    Two equally contributing users should be paid equally. For any i,j∈[N]:U​(𝝆S∪{i})=U​(𝝆S∪{j})​∀S⊂[N]\{i,j}⟹ϕi​(𝝆)=ϕj​(𝝆):𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑁𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑖𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑗for-all𝑆\delimited-[]𝑁𝑖𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗𝝆i,j\in[N]:U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{i\}})=U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{j\}})\;\;\forall S\subset[N]\backslash\{i,j\}\implies\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho})=\phi_{j}(\bm{\rho}).

    In addition, for any user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N], U​(𝝆S∪{i})−U​(𝝆S)=0​∀S⊂[N]\{i}⟹ϕi​(𝝆)=0𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑖𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆0for-all𝑆\delimited-[]𝑁𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆0U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{i\}})-U(\bm{\rho}_{S})=0\;\;\forall S\subset[N]\backslash\{i\}\implies\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho})=0.

  2. B.ii)

    The sum of all payments is an α​(ϵ)𝛼italic-ϵ\bm{\alpha}(\bm{\epsilon}) fraction of the total utility. The sum of values is the total utility α​(𝝆)​U​(𝝆)=∑iϕi​(𝝆)𝛼𝝆𝑈𝝆subscript𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\alpha(\bm{\rho})U(\bm{\rho})=\sum_{i}\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}). Where if U​(𝝆)=U​(𝝆~)𝑈𝝆𝑈~𝝆U(\bm{\rho})=U(\tilde{\bm{\rho}}) then α​(𝝆)=α​(𝝆~)𝛼𝝆𝛼~𝝆\alpha(\bm{\rho})=\alpha(\tilde{\bm{\rho}}) and 0≤α​(𝝆)≤10𝛼𝝆10\leq\alpha(\bm{\rho})\leq 1.

  3. B.iii)

    If two utility functions are combined, the payment for the combined task should be the sum of the individual tasks. Let ϕi​(𝝆)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) be the value of users for the utility function U𝑈U, under the ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-private algorithm A𝝆subscript𝐴𝝆A_{\bm{\rho}}. Let V𝑉V be a separate utility function, also based on the output of the algorithm Aϵsubscript𝐴bold-italic-ϵA_{\bm{\epsilon}}, and let ϕi′​(𝝆)subscriptsuperscriptitalic-ϕ′𝑖𝝆\phi^{\prime}_{i}(\bm{\rho}) be the utility of the users with respect to V𝑉V. Then under the utility U+V𝑈𝑉U+V, the value of user i𝑖i is ϕi​(𝝆)+ϕi′​(𝝆)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖′𝝆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho})+\phi_{i}^{\prime}(\bm{\rho}).

A notable difference between these axioms and (A.i-iii) is that the efficiency condition is replaced with pseudo-efficiency. Under this condition, the platform may determine the sum of payments awarded to the players, but this sum should in general depend only on the utility itself, and not on how that utility is achieved.

Theorem 2.

Let ϕi​(𝛒)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝛒\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) satisfying axioms (B.i-iii) represent the portion of total utility awarded to each user i𝑖i from utility U​(𝛒)𝑈𝛒U(\bm{\rho}). Then for α​(𝛒)𝛼𝛒\alpha({\bm{\rho}}) that satisfies axiom (B.ii)ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\;\phi_{i} takes the form:

ϕi​(𝝆)=α​(𝝆)N​∑S⊆[N]\{i}1(N−1|S|)​(U​(𝝆S∪{i})−U​(𝝆S)).subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆𝛼𝝆𝑁subscript𝑆\delimited-[]𝑁𝑖1binomial𝑁1𝑆𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑖𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho})=\frac{\alpha(\bm{\rho})}{N}\sum_{S\subseteq[N]\backslash\{i\}}\frac{1}{\binom{N-1}{\left\lvert{S}\right\rvert}}\left(U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{i\}})-U(\bm{\rho}_{S})\right). (5)

The proof of Theorem 2 can be found in Appendix B.2. This result is similar to the classic Shapley value (Shapley, 1952), but differs in its novel asymmetric treatment of the platform.

Computational Complexity

At first glance it may seem that both notions of fairness have exponential computational complexity of N​|ℰ|N𝑁superscriptℰ𝑁N\left\lvert{\mathcal{E}}\right\rvert^{N}. This is only true for a worst-case exact computation. In order for these notions to be useful in any meaningful way, we must be able to compute them. Thankfully, in practice, U𝑈U typically has a structure that makes the problem more tractable. In Ghorbani & Zou (2019), Jia et al. (2019), Wang & Jia (2023) and Lundberg & Lee (2017) special structures are used to compute the types of Shapley value sums we are considering with significantly reduced complexity, particularly in cases where the U𝑈U is related to the accuracy of a deep network. This is critical because we want to compute fair values for large number of users. For example, our platform could be a medical data network with hundreds of hospitals as our users, or a smartphone company with millions of users, and we need to be able to scale computation to accurately compute these fair values.

Example: Differentially Private Estimation

In this example, we use DP as our heterogeneous privacy framework. Let Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i} represent independent and identically distributed data of user i𝑖i respectively, with Pr​(Xi=1/2)=pPrsubscript𝑋𝑖12𝑝\text{Pr}(X_{i}=1/2)=p and Pr​(Xi=−1/2)=1−pPrsubscript𝑋𝑖121𝑝\text{Pr}(X_{i}=-1/2)=1-p, with p∼Unif​(0,1)similar-to𝑝Unif01p\sim\text{Unif}(0,1). The platform’s goal is to construct an ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP estimator for μ:=𝔼​[Xi]=p−1/2assign𝜇𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑋𝑖𝑝12\mu\vcentcolon=\mathbb{E}[X_{i}]=p-1/2 that minimizes Bayes risk. There is no general procedure for finding the Bayes optimal ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP estimator, so restrict our attention to ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP linear-Laplace estimators of the form:

A​(𝐗)=𝐰​(ϵ)T​𝐗+Z,𝐴𝐗𝐰superscriptbold-italic-ϵ𝑇𝐗𝑍A(\mathbf{X})=\mathbf{w}(\bm{\epsilon})^{T}\mathbf{X}+Z, (6)

where Z∼Laplace​(1/η​(ϵ))similar-to𝑍Laplace1𝜂bold-italic-ϵZ\sim\text{Laplace}(1/\eta(\bm{\epsilon})). In Fallah et al. (2022) the authors argue that unbiased linear estimators are nearly optimal in a minimax sense for bounded random variables. We assume a squared error loss L​(a,μ)=(a−μ)2𝐿𝑎𝜇superscript𝑎𝜇2L(a,\mu)=(a-\mu)^{2} and let 𝒜lin​(ϵ)subscript𝒜linbold-italic-ϵ\mathcal{A}_{\text{lin}}(\bm{\epsilon}) be the set of ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP estimators satisfying equation 6. Then, we define:

Aϵ=arg​minA∈𝒜lin​(ϵ)⁡𝔼​[L​(A​(𝐗),μ)]r​(ϵ)=𝔼​[L​(Aϵ​(𝐗),μ)].formulae-sequencesubscript𝐴bold-italic-ϵsubscriptargmin𝐴subscript𝒜linbold-italic-ϵ𝔼delimited-[]𝐿𝐴𝐗𝜇𝑟bold-italic-ϵ𝔼delimited-[]𝐿subscript𝐴bold-italic-ϵ𝐗𝜇A_{\bm{\epsilon}}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{A\in\mathcal{A}_{\text{lin}}(\bm{\epsilon})}\mathbb{E}[L(A(\mathbf{X}),\mu)]\quad\quad r(\bm{\epsilon})=\mathbb{E}[L(A_{\bm{\epsilon}}(\mathbf{X}),\mu)]. (7)

In words, Aϵsubscript𝐴bold-italic-ϵA_{\bm{\epsilon}} is an ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}-DP estimator of the form equation 6, where 𝐰​(ϵ)𝐰bold-italic-ϵ\mathbf{w}(\mathbf{\bm{\epsilon}}) and η​(ϵ)𝜂bold-italic-ϵ\eta(\bm{\epsilon}) are chosen to minimize the Bayes risk of the estimator, and r​(ϵ)𝑟bold-italic-ϵr(\bm{\epsilon}) is the risk achieved by Aϵsubscript𝐴bold-italic-ϵA_{\bm{\epsilon}}. Since the platform’s goal is to accurately estimate the mean of the data, it is natural for the utility U​(ϵ)𝑈bold-italic-ϵU(\bm{\epsilon}) to depend on ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon} through the risk function r​(ϵ)𝑟bold-italic-ϵr(\bm{\epsilon}). Note that if U𝑈U is monotone decreasing in r​(ϵ)𝑟bold-italic-ϵr(\bm{\epsilon}), then U𝑈U is monotone increasing in ϵbold-italic-ϵ\bm{\epsilon}. Let us now consider the case of N=2𝑁2N=2 users, choosing from an action space of ℰ={0,ϵ′}ℰ0superscriptitalic-ϵ′\mathcal{E}=\{0,{\epsilon}^{\prime}\}, for some ϵ′>0superscriptitalic-ϵ′0{\epsilon}^{\prime}>0. Furthermore, take U𝑈U to be an affine function of r​(ϵ)𝑟bold-italic-ϵr(\bm{\epsilon}): U​(ϵ)=c1​r​(ϵ)+c2𝑈bold-italic-ϵsubscript𝑐1𝑟bold-italic-ϵsubscript𝑐2U(\bm{\epsilon})=c_{1}r(\bm{\epsilon})+c_{2}. 4 Fair Incentives in Federated Learning

FL is a distributed learning process used when data is either too large or too sensitive to be directly transferred in full to the platform. Instead of combining all the data together and learning at the platform, each user performs some part of the learning locally and the results are aggregated at the platform, providing some level of privacy. Donahue & Kleinberg (2021) consider a setting where heterogeneous users voluntarily opt-in to federation. A natural question to ask is: how much less valuable to the platform is a user that chooses to federate with others as compared to one that provides full access to their data? Furthermore, how should the platform allocate incentives to get users to federate? This section addresses these questions.

Each user i∈[N]𝑖delimited-[]𝑁i\in[N] has a unique mean and variance (θi,σi2)∼Θsimilar-tosubscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2Θ(\theta_{i},\sigma_{i}^{2})\sim\Theta, where ΘΘ\Theta is some global joint distribution. Let θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} represent some information about the user critical for advertising. We wish to learn θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} as accurately as possible to maximize our profits, by serving the best advertisements possible to each user.

User i𝑖i draws nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} samples i.i.d. from its local distribution 𝒟i​(θi,σi2)subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}(\theta_{i},\sigma^{2}_{i}), that is, some distribution with mean θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} and variance σi2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2𝑖\sigma^{2}_{i}. Let s2=Var​(θi)superscript𝑠2Varsubscript𝜃𝑖s^{2}=\mathrm{Var}(\theta_{i}) represent the variance between users and r2=𝔼​[σi2]superscript𝑟2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑖2r^{2}=\mathbb{E}[\sigma_{i}^{2}] represent the variance within a user’s data. When s2≫r2/nimuch-greater-thansuperscript𝑠2superscript𝑟2subscript𝑛𝑖s^{2}\gg r^{2}/n_{i} the data is very heterogeneous, and it is generally not helpful to include much information from the other users when estimating θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, however, if s2≪r2/nimuch-less-thansuperscript𝑠2superscript𝑟2subscript𝑛𝑖s^{2}\ll r^{2}/n_{i}, the situation is reversed, and information from the other users will be very useful. The goal of the platform is to construct estimators θ^ipsubscriptsuperscript^𝜃𝑝𝑖\hat{\theta}^{p}_{i} while respecting the privacy level vector 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}:

EMSEi​(𝝆):=𝔼​[(θ^ip​(𝝆)−θi)2].assignsubscriptEMSE𝑖𝝆𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑖𝑝𝝆subscript𝜃𝑖2\mathrm{EMSE}_{i}(\bm{\rho})\vcentcolon=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\hat{\theta}_{i}^{p}(\bm{\rho})-\theta_{i}\right)^{2}\right]. (11)

Fig. 2 summarizes our FL formulation. Users can choose from a 333-level privacy space ℰ={0,1,2}ℰ012\mathcal{E}=\{0,1,2\}. In this case the privacy space is not related to DP, but instead encodes how users choose to share their data with the platform. Let Njsubscript𝑁𝑗N_{j} be the number of users that choose privacy level j𝑗j. The heterogeneous privacy framework is given in Table 1.

Note that the error in estimating θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} depends not just on the privacy level of the i𝑖ith user ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}, but on the entire privacy vector. Let the users be ordered such that ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} is a non-increasing sequence. Then for each i𝑖i the platform constructs estimators of the form:

θ^ip=wi​0​θ^f+∑j=1N2wi​j​θ^j,superscriptsubscript^𝜃𝑖𝑝subscript𝑤𝑖0superscript^𝜃𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝑁2subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗subscript^𝜃𝑗\hat{\theta}_{i}^{p}=w_{i0}\hat{\theta}^{f}+\sum_{j=1}^{N_{2}}w_{ij}\hat{\theta}_{j}, (12)

where, ∑jwi​j=1subscript𝑗subscript𝑤𝑖𝑗1\sum_{j}w_{ij}=1 for all i𝑖i. In Proposition 5, found in Appendix B.3, we calculate the optimal choice of wi​jsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗w_{ij} which depends on 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}. From these estimators, the platform generates utility U​(𝝆)𝑈𝝆U(\bm{\rho}). The optimal wi​0subscript𝑤𝑖0w_{i0} and wi​jsubscript𝑤𝑖𝑗w_{ij} in equation 12 are well defined in a Bayesian sense if ρi>0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}>0 for some i𝑖i, but this does not make sense when 𝝆=𝟎𝝆0\bm{\rho}=\bm{0}. We can get around this by defining EMSEi​(𝟎):=r2+2​s2assignsubscriptEMSE𝑖0superscript𝑟22superscript𝑠2\mathrm{EMSE}_{i}(\mathbf{0})\vcentcolon=r^{2}+2s^{2}. For the purposes of our discussion, we assume a logarithmic form utility function. This logarithmic form is common in utility theories dating back at least to Kelly (1956). In the following section, we make a diminishing returns assumption to derive our theoretical result, which the logarithmic utility satisfies. The exact utility function we consider is:

U​(𝝆):=∑i=1nai​log⁡((r2+2​s2)EMSEi​(𝝆)).assign𝑈𝝆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑎𝑖superscript𝑟22superscript𝑠2subscriptEMSE𝑖𝝆U(\bm{\rho})\vcentcolon=\sum_{i=1}^{n}a_{i}\log\left(\frac{(r^{2}+2s^{2})}{\mathrm{EMSE}_{i}(\bm{\rho})}\right). (13)

aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} represents the relative importance of each user. This is important to model because some users may spend more than others, and are thus more important to the platform i.e., the platform may care about computing their θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} more accurately than the other users. The argument of the log\log is increasing as the EMSE decreases. The log\log means there is diminishing returns as each θ^isubscript^𝜃𝑖\hat{\theta}_{i} becomes more accurate.

4.1 Fair Payments Under Optional Federation

In this section, we focus on our definition of fairness in Theorem 2 and analyze the fair values ϕi​(𝝆)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) that are induced when using that notion of fairness. Let there be N=10𝑁10N=10 users. N1=5subscript𝑁15N_{1}=5 of these users opt for federating (ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1), N2=4subscript𝑁24N_{2}=4 directly provide their data to the platform (ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2), and finally, N0=1subscript𝑁01N_{0}=1 user chooses to not participate (ρi=0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}=0). In this subsection (and Fig. 5), without loss of generality, we assume α​(𝝆)=1𝛼𝝆1\alpha(\bm{\rho})=1, and the results of this section can be scaled accordingly. The choices of ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} for each user depends on their individual privacy sensitivity functions cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}, but we defer that discussion to the next subsection.

Different Amounts of Data

Fig 5(a) plots the difference from an equal distribution of utility, i.e., how much each user’s utility differs from U​(𝝆)/N𝑈𝝆𝑁U(\bm{\rho})/N. We assume ai=1subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}=1 for all users. In the bars furthest to the left, where s2=100superscript𝑠2100s^{2}=100 and r2=1superscript𝑟21r^{2}=1, we are in a very heterogeneous environment. Intuitively, this means that a user j𝑗j will have data that may not be helpful for estimating θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} for j≠i𝑗𝑖j\neq i, thus those users that choose ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2 are paid the most, since at the very least, the information they provide can be used to target their own θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}. Likewise, users that federate obfuscate where their data is coming from, making their data less valuable (since their own θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} cannot be targeted), so users with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 are paid less than an even allocation. On the right side, we have a regime where s2=0.1superscript𝑠20.1s^{2}=0.1 and r2=100superscript𝑟2100r^{2}=100, meaning users are similar and user data more exchangeable. Now users with larger nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are paid above the average utility per user, while those with lower nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} are paid less. Users with ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2 still receive more than those with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 when nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is fixed, and this difference is significant when ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100. In the center we have an intermediate regime of heterogeneity, where s2=1superscript𝑠21s^{2}=1 and r2=10superscript𝑟210r^{2}=10. Differences in payments appear less pronounced, interpolating between the two extremes.

More Valuable Users

Fig 5(b) is like Fig 5(a), except now in each set of graphs, exactly one user has ai=100subscript𝑎𝑖100a_{i}=100, meaning that estimating θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i} for user i𝑖i is 100100100 times more important than the others. Looking at the two leftmost sets of bars in Fig 5(b) we see that when user i𝑖i with ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2 and ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100 is the most important one, when s2superscript𝑠2s^{2} is large compared to r2superscript𝑟2r^{2}, it is user i𝑖i who receives most of the benefit in terms of its payment but when s2superscript𝑠2s^{2} is smaller, other users also benefit. This can be intuitively explained as follows: if users are very heterogeneous, other users j≠i𝑗𝑖j\neq i do not have data that is helpful for determining θisubscript𝜃𝑖\theta_{i}, thus they do not benefit when user i𝑖i has a larger aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}. Likewise, when s2superscript𝑠2s^{2} is small compared to r2superscript𝑟2r^{2} not just user i𝑖i benefits, but also all those users that contribute more data, as those users with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 and ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100 are also paid over the average utility per user. Another key point is the similarity between the second and fourth set of graphs. This tells an interesting story: when users are not very heterogeneous, regardless of which user is has ai=100subscript𝑎𝑖100a_{i}=100, it is those users with large nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} that will benefit.

4.2 Platform and User Game - Mechanism Design

Nash Equilibrium Under Fair Payments

We have just discussed how the fair values ϕi​(𝝆)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) change depending on the model parameters, and the choices of privacy level ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}. Now we discuss how the users come to decide their ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}. We again focus on the notion of privacy in Theorem 2, but we now restrict α​(𝝆)=α∈[0,1]𝛼𝝆𝛼01\alpha(\bm{\rho})=\alpha\in[0,1]. To avoid overly complicating the model, we take ai=1subscript𝑎𝑖1a_{i}=1 for all users. User i𝑖i chooses their privacy level ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} based on both the payments that they receive from the platform α​ϕi​(ρi;𝝆−i)𝛼subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖\alpha\phi_{i}(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i}) as well as their own unique privacy sensitivity function ci​(ρi)subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖c_{i}(\rho_{i}). In this context, we can view each user as optimizing their own local utility function:

ui​(ρi,𝝆−i):=α​ϕ​(ρi;𝝆−i)−ci​(ρi).assignsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖𝛼italic-ϕsubscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖u_{i}(\rho_{i},\bm{\rho}_{-i})\vcentcolon=\alpha\phi(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i})-c_{i}(\rho_{i}). (14)

User i𝑖i individually optimizes this function to determine their best response (denoted BRisubscriptBR𝑖\mathrm{BR}_{i}) to the choices of the other users and the platform:

BRi​(𝝆−i,α):=arg​maxρi⁡ui​(ρi,𝝆−i)assignsubscriptBR𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖𝛼subscriptargmaxsubscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖\mathrm{BR}_{i}(\bm{\rho}_{-i},\alpha)\vcentcolon=\operatorname*{arg\,max}_{\rho_{i}}u_{i}(\rho_{i},\bm{\rho}_{-i}) (15)

The full best response function BR​(𝝆,α):=[BR1​(𝝆−1,α),…,BRN​(𝝆−N,α)]TassignBR𝝆𝛼superscriptsubscriptBR1subscript𝝆1𝛼…subscriptBR𝑁subscript𝝆𝑁𝛼𝑇\mathrm{BR}(\bm{\rho},\alpha)\vcentcolon=\left[\mathrm{BR}_{1}(\bm{\rho}_{-1},\alpha),\dots,\mathrm{BR}_{N}(\bm{\rho}_{-N},\alpha)\right]^{T} is a vector that collects all users’ individual best response functions. The “fixed points” of the best response at a given α𝛼\alpha constitute the pure-strategy NEs:

NE​(α):={𝝆:𝝆=BR​(𝝆,α)}.assignNE𝛼conditional-set𝝆𝝆BR𝝆𝛼\text{NE}(\alpha)\vcentcolon=\left\{\bm{\rho}:\bm{\rho}=\mathrm{BR}(\bm{\rho},\alpha)\right\}. (16)

Fig 6 depicts a particular fixed point of the best response function (therefore a NE) in our federated mean estimation example. Each of the N=10𝑁10N=10 users in assigned one of 5 unique sensitivity functions cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}, which are shown in the figure.

Solving the Fair Data Acquisition Problem

The platform’s goal is to set α𝛼\alpha such that it maximizes the total amount of utility it receives. Since the NE set depends on α𝛼\alpha the platform has some control over the behavior of the users. The mechanism design problem in this case reduces to: {maxi}<b > α, ρ (1 - α)U(ρ) \addConstraint ρ∈NE(α). Note that this is exactly equation 1, except we have used the fact that α​(𝝆)​U​(𝝆)=∑iϕi​(𝝆)𝛼𝝆𝑈𝝆subscript𝑖subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\alpha(\bm{\rho})U(\bm{\rho})=\sum_{i}\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}). Solving equation 4.2 is a daunting task, due to the complex structure of the constraint, however, it is numerically tractable in this case. The key idea to efficiently solve equation 4.2 is to exploit symmetries in the utility function. For instance, if 𝝆′superscript𝝆′\bm{\rho}^{\prime} is constructed from 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho} by permuting the values ρi,ρjsubscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝜌𝑗\rho_{i},\rho_{j} where ni=njsubscript𝑛𝑖subscript𝑛𝑗n_{i}=n_{j}, then U​(𝝆)=U​(𝝆′)𝑈𝝆𝑈superscript𝝆′U(\bm{\rho})=U(\bm{\rho}^{\prime}). This allows us compute ϕi​(𝝆)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝝆\phi_{i}(\bm{\rho}) for a much smaller number of representative 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}, rather than a full combinatorial search. Despite producing the same utility, 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho} and 𝝆′superscript𝝆′\bm{\rho}^{\prime} may have very different stability properties. To deal this this, we can implement an efficient tree search to identify the NEs within each group. Once we have an efficient algorithm for computing NEs, we conduct a grid search to determine the optimal α𝛼\alpha. Note that for an arbitrary problem, finding the equilibria can be a challenging task, and thus the more difficult it is to compute the equilibria, the more difficult it will be to solve the design problem in equation 1. We provide a full description of our solution in Appendix D.

Fig 7 shows the numerical solution to equation 4.2 for two different choices of s2superscript𝑠2s^{2} and r2superscript𝑟2r^{2}. Fig 7(a) is a more homogeneous setting and we observe that the optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} sets the payment just high enough so that both of the users with ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100 choose to participate at ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1, while all other users choose ρi=0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}=0. Essentially, the platform identifies the two users with ni=100subscript𝑛𝑖100n_{i}=100, and focused on collecting their data, rather than the data of the other 8 users. This configuration collects a majority of the data for relatively little payment. Since the data is very homogeneous anyways, the platform is not losing much utility by allowing those two users to choose ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1 rather than ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2. As the platform increases α𝛼\alpha, more users choose to participate, eventually with many of them choosing ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2, however, the benefit is minimal, and it is outweighed by the extra payments that are required to achieve that outcome. Fig 7(b) covers a more heterogeneous setting. In this setting, we see that α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} is higher, and a larger fraction of the total utility is paid to users. For this α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} only two of the users do not choose ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2. There is also one user with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1, and one with ρi=0subscript𝜌𝑖0\rho_{i}=0 that have a higher privacy sensitivities. In the more heterogeneous setting, allowing users to choose a private option is more costly, so the extra payment to ensure more user choose ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2 is worthwhile in this regime.

Other Formulations

We conclude this section by remarking that this is just one particular formulation of a federated learning problem where users have privacy choice. Another interesting formulation can be found in Aldaghri et al. (2023), which comes from the literature on personalized federated learning Li et al. (2021). In this formulation, all users join the federated learning process, but some users can choose between a private option, where their data is protected via differential privacy, or a standard non-private option. Exploring fair incentives in this, and other models could be an interesting direction for future work.

5 Fairness Constraints: Data Acquisition

In the previous section, we considered a complex model, numerically studying the equilibria of the users based on fair payments from the platform, as well as how the platform optimally chooses α𝛼\alpha. In this section, we consider a tractable model and theoretically study how the optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} changes based on the privacy sensitivity of users, under a fairness framework based on Theorem 2. This section addresses this problem by investigating the incentives of a platform designing a mechanism under the constraint of fairness.

Consider N≥2𝑁2N\geq 2 users each with identical statistical marginal contribution, i.e., for any i,j𝑖𝑗i,j we have S⊆[N]\{i,j}𝑆\delimited-[]𝑁𝑖𝑗S\subseteq[N]\backslash\{i,j\}, U​(𝝆S∪{i})=U​(𝝆S∪{j})𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑖𝑈subscript𝝆𝑆𝑗U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{i\}})=U(\bm{\rho}_{S\cup\{j\}}). The platform is restricted to making fair payments satisfying axioms (B.i-iii) with the additional constraint that α​(𝝆)=α∈[0,1]𝛼𝝆𝛼01\alpha(\bm{\rho})=\alpha\in[0,1]. Users choose one of two available privacy levels ρi∈ℰNsubscript𝜌𝑖superscriptℰ𝑁\rho_{i}\in\mathcal{E}^{N}, with ℰ={ρ1′,ρ2′}ℰsubscriptsuperscript𝜌′1subscriptsuperscript𝜌′2\mathcal{E}=\{\rho^{\prime}_{1},\rho^{\prime}_{2}\} and ρ2′>ρ1′subscriptsuperscript𝜌′2subscriptsuperscript𝜌′1\rho^{\prime}_{2}>\rho^{\prime}_{1}. We can write the utility of the user i𝑖i as

u​(ρi,𝝆−i)=α​ϕ​(ρi;𝝆−i)−c​𝟙​{ρi=ρ2′}.𝑢subscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖𝛼italic-ϕsubscript𝜌𝑖subscript𝝆𝑖𝑐1subscript𝜌𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜌′2u(\rho_{i},\bm{\rho}_{-i})=\alpha\phi(\rho_{i};\bm{\rho}_{-i})-c\mathds{1}\left\{{\rho_{i}=\rho^{\prime}_{2}}\right\}. (17)

Users gain utility from incentives provided by the platform but incur a cost of c𝑐c if they choose the less private option. For now, we assume c𝑐c is the same for all users; later we discuss the case where c𝑐c is different. Note that we can drop the index of ϕisubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖\phi_{i} due to the assumption of equal marginal contribution. To enrich the problem, we allow users to employ a mixed strategy denoted by 𝐩=[p,(1−p)]T𝐩superscript𝑝1𝑝𝑇\mathbf{p}=[p,(1-p)]^{T}, where users choose the ρ1′superscriptsubscript𝜌1′\rho_{1}^{\prime} with probability p𝑝p and ρ2′superscriptsubscript𝜌2′\rho_{2}^{\prime} with probability 1−p1𝑝1-p. This is justified because we expect users to repeatedly interact with platforms and sample from their mixed strategy and ultimately converge to their expected utility.

The platform is also trying to maximize the fraction of the total expected utility U​(𝐩):=𝔼𝝆∼𝐩​[U​(𝝆)]assign𝑈𝐩subscript𝔼similar-to𝝆𝐩delimited-[]𝑈𝝆U(\mathbf{p})\vcentcolon=\mathbb{E}_{\bm{\rho}\sim\mathbf{p}}\left[U(\bm{\rho})\right] that it keeps as in equation 1. The platform’s goal is to choose a payment value α𝛼\alpha such that it optimizes: {maxi}<b > α(1 - α)U(p^*(α)) \addConstraint p^*(α) ∈NE(α). The objective is simplified compared to equation 1 by exploiting the pseudo-efficiency axiom, which says that the sum of payments is α𝛼\alpha times the total utility. The constraint in equation 5 implicitly encodes the user behavior governed by equation 17, and will change with the privacy sensitivity c𝑐c. Theorem 3 characterizes the solution of equation 5 for different values of c𝑐c. To make equation 5 amenable to insightful analysis, we make some mild assumptions.

Assumption 1.

The utility U𝑈U is monotone: 𝛒S(2)≥𝛒S(1)⟹U​(𝛒S(2))>U​(𝛒S(1))​∀S⊆[N]superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑆2superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑆1𝑈superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑆2𝑈superscriptsubscript𝛒𝑆1for-all𝑆delimited-[]𝑁\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(2)}\geq\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(1)}\implies U(\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(2)})>U(\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(1)})\;\;\forall S\subseteq[N].

Assumption 2.

The utility U𝑈U has diminishing returns. Let nprivate​(𝛒S)subscript𝑛privatesubscript𝛒𝑆n_{\text{private}}(\bm{\rho}_{S}) represent the number of elements of i∈S𝑖𝑆i\in S such that ρi=ρ1′subscript𝜌𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜌1′\rho_{i}=\rho_{1}^{\prime}, i.e., the number of users choosing the higher privacy option. Furthermore, define Δi​U​(𝛒S):=U​(𝛒S(i+))−U​(𝛒S)assignsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑈subscript𝛒𝑆𝑈subscriptsuperscript𝛒limit-from𝑖𝑆𝑈subscript𝛒𝑆\Delta_{i}U(\bm{\rho}_{S})\vcentcolon=U(\bm{\rho}^{(i+)}_{S})-U(\bm{\rho}_{S}), where 𝛒S(i+)subscriptsuperscript𝛒limit-from𝑖𝑆\bm{\rho}^{(i+)}_{S} is equal to 𝛒Ssubscript𝛒𝑆\bm{\rho}_{S} except ρi(i+)=ρ2′subscriptsuperscript𝜌limit-from𝑖𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝜌′2\rho^{(i+)}_{i}=\rho^{\prime}_{2}. In other words, Δi​U​(𝛒S)subscriptΔ𝑖𝑈subscript𝛒𝑆\Delta_{i}U(\bm{\rho}_{S}) is the marginal increase in utility when the i𝑖ith user switches to the lower privacy option. Then U𝑈U satisfies:

nprivate​(𝝆S(1))≥nprivate​(𝝆S(2))⟹Δi​U​(𝝆(1))>Δi​U​(𝝆(2)).subscript𝑛privatesuperscriptsubscript𝝆𝑆1subscript𝑛privatesuperscriptsubscript𝝆𝑆2subscriptΔ𝑖𝑈superscript𝝆1subscriptΔ𝑖𝑈superscript𝝆2n_{\text{private}}(\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(1)})\geq n_{\text{private}}(\bm{\rho}_{S}^{(2)})\implies\Delta_{i}U(\bm{\rho}^{(1)})>\Delta_{i}U(\bm{\rho}^{(2)}). (18)

It is helpful to define the expected relative payoff, where the expectation is taken with respect to the actions of the other players. When all other users choose a mixed strategy 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}, the expected relative payoff is defined as:

γ​(p):=ϕ​(ρ2′;𝐩)−ϕ​(ρ1′;𝐩)=𝔼ρj∼𝐩j≠i​[ϕ​(ρ2′;𝝆−i)−ϕ​(ρ1′;𝝆−i)].assign𝛾𝑝italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜌2′𝐩italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜌1′𝐩subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝜌𝑗𝐩𝑗𝑖delimited-[]italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝜌′2subscript𝝆𝑖italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝜌′1subscript𝝆𝑖\gamma(p)\vcentcolon=\phi(\rho_{2}^{\prime};\mathbf{p})-\phi(\rho_{1}^{\prime};\mathbf{p})=\mathbb{E}_{\begin{subarray}{c}\rho_{j}\sim\mathbf{p}\\ j\neq i\end{subarray}}\left[\phi(\rho^{\prime}_{2};\bm{\rho}_{-i})-\phi(\rho^{\prime}_{1};\bm{\rho}_{-i})\right]. (19)

For convenience, we have defined γ𝛾\gamma in terms of the scalar p𝑝p, rather than the vector 𝐩=[p,(1−p)]T𝐩superscript𝑝1𝑝𝑇\mathbf{p}=[p,\;(1-p)]^{T}. This quantity represents the expected gain in incentive (normalized to make it invariant to α𝛼\alpha) if a user switches to a less private level from the more private level given everyone else plays the mixed strategy 𝐩𝐩\mathbf{p}.

Theorem 3.

Consider a binary privacy level game with N𝑁N users and a platform. If U𝑈U satisfies Assumptions 1 and 2, and the platform payments are fair as defined in Theorem 2 with constant α𝛼\alpha then the optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} can be divided into three regimes depending on c𝑐c. The boundaries of these regions are γm​a​x:=maxp⁡γ​(p)assignsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥subscript𝑝𝛾𝑝\gamma_{max}\vcentcolon=\max_{p}\gamma(p) and some ct​h<γm​a​xsubscript𝑐𝑡ℎsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥c_{th}<\gamma_{max} such that:

  1. 1.

    When c>γm​a​x𝑐subscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥c>\gamma_{max}, α∗=0superscript𝛼0\alpha^{*}=0 is the maximizer of 5.

  2. 2.

    When ct​h<c<γm​a​xsubscript𝑐𝑡ℎ𝑐subscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥c_{th}<c<\gamma_{max} then α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} is the minimizing α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] such that p∗​(α)∈γ−1​(c/α)superscript𝑝𝛼superscript𝛾1𝑐𝛼p^{*}(\alpha)\in\gamma^{-1}(c/\alpha).

  3. 3.

    When c<ct​h𝑐subscript𝑐𝑡ℎc<c_{th}: α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} is the smallest α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1] such that p​(α)=0𝑝𝛼0p(\alpha)=0, where

ct​h=max{c|1−c/γm​i​n1−α−U​(p∗​(α))U​(0)≥0∀α≤c/γm​i​n}.c_{th}=\max\left\{c\left\lvert\frac{1-c/\gamma_{min}}{1-\alpha}-\frac{U(p^{*}(\alpha))}{U(0)}\geq 0\;\;\forall\alpha\leq c/\gamma_{min}\right.\right\}. (20)

Theorem 3 can be interpreted as follows. If privacy sensitivity is above γm​a​xsubscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥\gamma_{max} for the given task, it is not worth the effort of the platform to participate. On the other hand, if privacy sensitivity is less than ct​hsubscript𝑐𝑡ℎc_{th}, the platform should set α𝛼\alpha to be as small as possible, while still ensuring that all users choose the low privacy setting. Finally, if privacy sensitivities lie somewhere in between, α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} should be chosen based on the γ𝛾\gamma function, and generally will lead to a mixed strategy with some proportion of users choosing each of the two options.

Comparison to other works

Two key novelties of our work is that we (1) consider a constraint of fairness and (2) have users choose a privacy level, rather than report their privacy sensitivity. This is different from Fallah et al. (2022), and Cummings et al. (2023), which rely on incentive compatibility, and have users report their privacy parameters. In Fallah et al. (2022), a computationally efficient algorithm is proposed for computing user payments and privacy levels to assign users. Both of these works consider a mean estimation problem, where users have i.i.d. samples, and so also have the “equal marginal contribution” assumption that we have. Distinct from our model, users have an additional term in their utility where they benefit from reduced error in the estimation problem. These works focus on maximizing the platform utility, and it is very clear that the payments deviate significantly from the fair ones that satisfy the fairness axioms. Hu & Gong (2020) is perhaps the work most relevant to ours. They consider an incentive design problem where the platform fixes the total sum of payments R𝑅R and the amount each user receives is proportional to their privacy level ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i}, which the users choose. This proportional scheme, while potentially viewed as a type of fairness, does not satisfy our axioms. For a particular utility function, they develop a computationally efficient algorithm to compute the equilibrium privacy levels ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} based on the privacy sensitivities of the users and the total sum of payments R𝑅R. In all of these works, users have a linear privacy sensitivity function with rate cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}.

Though this seems different from our binary privacy problem, there is a direct correspondence here since we allow mixed strategies, so in expectation, our sensitivity is also reduced to a linear function of the mixed strategy: i.e., 𝔼​[ci​𝟙​{ρi=ρ2′}]=ci​Pr​(ρi=ρ2′)𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑐𝑖1subscript𝜌𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜌2′subscript𝑐𝑖Prsubscript𝜌𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜌2′\mathbb{E}\left[c_{i}\mathds{1}\left\{{\rho_{i}=\rho_{2}^{\prime}}\right\}\right]=c_{i}\mathrm{Pr}(\rho_{i}=\rho_{2}^{\prime}).

5.1 Mechanism Design: Mean Estimation Example

Let’s look at the utility function from equation 9, and fair payments that we calculated from Theorem 2 in equation 8. In this case there are N=2𝑁2N=2 users, and we will assume each user has a sensitivity function as in equation 17. This setting satisfies the conditions of Theorem 3, and so we can use our above result to characterize the optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} to equation 5 for a range of different c𝑐c values. That is, as the privacy sensitivity parameter c𝑐c changes, how is the optimal strategy of the platform impacted? Fig. 8 depicts the solution to equation 5. The top plot shows the optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} vs. c𝑐c, while the bottom plot shows the total utility and the fraction of utility paid to each user at the optimal point α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} for a range of c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1].

As predicted by Theorem 3, we find that the solution is clearly divided into three regions. Equation 20 tells us that ct​h=13subscript𝑐𝑡ℎ13c_{th}=\frac{1}{3} and γm​a​x=23subscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥23\gamma_{max}=\frac{2}{3}, matching our observations in Fig. 8. In the first region when c≤13𝑐13c\leq\frac{1}{3} the privacy sensitivity of the users is low, and the platform is able to capture most of the utility for itself, paying less of it out to the users. In this region, α∗=2​csuperscript𝛼2𝑐\alpha^{*}=2c, growing linearly with the privacy sensitivity. We also see that throughout this regime, the total utility is maximized, as predicted by the theory. In the region where c∈[13,23]𝑐1323c\in[\frac{1}{3},\frac{2}{3}], optimal α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} is no longer growing linearly, and now grows as α∗=6​c3​c+2superscript𝛼6𝑐3𝑐2\alpha^{*}=\frac{6c}{3c+2} no longer have enough incentive to always choose the less private option, the total utility also begins to decrease, meaning less utility is available for incentives. These factors lead to a decrease in total utility in this region. As α∗superscript𝛼\alpha^{*} continues to increase towards 1. Once α∗=1superscript𝛼1\alpha^{*}=1 at c=23𝑐23c=\frac{2}{3}, the platform is getting no utility, so may as well choose α∗=0superscript𝛼0\alpha^{*}=0. Finally, for c≥23𝑐23c\geq\frac{2}{3}, the platform no longer attempts to incentivize the users, and the total utility and payments fall to zero with α∗=0superscript𝛼0\alpha^{*}=0.

For this particular example, it is possible to analytically solve the NE constraint in equation 5, exact analytic expressions for the curves in Fig. 8 are given in Appendix B.4.1.

5.2 Considering Different Privacy Sensitivities

The computational burden in solving equation 5 is in characterizing the constraint, since the objective reduces to a one-dimensional optimization over α∈[0,1]𝛼01\alpha\in[0,1]. In the previous section, with the knowledge that the game is symmetric, we are able to easily characterize the equilibria as a function of α𝛼\alpha. If the cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}’s are all different, for arbitrary utility functions, the problem essentially reduces to finding the equilibria in a general game. To make this tractable, we will need some assumptions. In Hu & Gong (2020), the specific choice of utility function and payments makes computation of the equilibrium tractable. If we have only two groups of users with different cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i} that act together, and a finite privacy space, we can appeal to tools for enumerating equilibria in matrix games (Avis et al., 2010). In this case if the privacy space is also binary, then the equilibria have an analytical solution, which we provide in Appendix E. Like the symmetric case, there are 3 cases for each of the two users as well as corresponding thresholds that depend on c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} respectively, resulting in 9 total cases. For example, in the case where payment is below the threshold of both users, neither participate at the low-privacy level, when the payment is high enough both participate at the low privacy level, and for the remaining intermediate cases, either only one user chooses the low privacy option, or there is some asymmetric mixed strategy. Below, we numerically investigate this case:

This problem differs from equation 5 because the equilibrium is governed by asymmetric users. For example, if user 1 and user 2 have privacy sensitivity c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} respectively, we have

u1​(𝐩1,𝐩2)=𝐩1T​𝚽1(2)​𝐩2−[0​c1]T​𝐩1,u2​(𝐩1,𝐩2)=𝐩1T​𝚽2(2)​𝐩2−[0​c2]T​𝐩2.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑢1subscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2superscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝚽21subscript𝐩2superscriptdelimited-[]0subscript𝑐1𝑇subscript𝐩1subscript𝑢2subscript𝐩1subscript𝐩2superscriptsubscript𝐩1𝑇subscriptsuperscript𝚽22subscript𝐩2superscriptdelimited-[]0subscript𝑐2𝑇subscript𝐩2u_{1}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2})=\mathbf{p}_{1}^{T}\mathbf{\Phi}^{(2)}_{1}\mathbf{p}_{2}-[0\;c_{1}]^{T}\mathbf{p}_{1},\quad u_{2}(\mathbf{p}_{1},\mathbf{p}_{2})=\mathbf{p}_{1}^{T}\mathbf{\Phi}^{(2)}_{2}\mathbf{p}_{2}-[0\;c_{2}]^{T}\mathbf{p}_{2}. (21)

Consider a setting where there are only two users (these can be thought of as representing two groups of users) with utility function u1subscript𝑢1u_{1} and u2subscript𝑢2u_{2} listed above. Fig. 9 plots the results of simulating the solution of 5.2. It shows that there is one region when c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} are both small and close together (<1/3absent13<1/3), the platform chooses α𝛼\alpha to collect data from both users. Broader Impact Statement

One of the unique defining characteristics of data is that its generation process is inherently distributed, so no single entity exists to advocate for data sellers. In the past, platforms have been able to extract data from users, often with little to no compensation in return. As public consciousness around privacy changes, a nuanced relationship around privacy between platforms and users must develop. Transparency and understanding the value of user data is an important step in empowering regulators, consumers, and platforms.

  • •

    Users making strategic decisions about when they share their data stand to gain from incentives.

  • •

    For regulators, understanding the amount of value that flows through the interactions between platforms can enable better policies around data. Frameworks like those discussed in Theorem 1 and 2 can be a starting point in understanding exactly how much this value is.

  • •

    For platforms, understanding which data tasks are economically viable, and how they allocate incentive is important. Our discussion in Section 5, and our three regimes help shed light on this.

6 Conclusion

This paper introduces two formal definitions of fair payments in the context of acquisition of private data. The first treats the users and the platform together and uses axioms like those of the Shapley value to determine a unique fair distribution of utility. In the second, we define a notion of fairness between the users only, leading to a definition of fairness that admits a range of values, of which the platform is free to choose the most favorable. By formulating a federated mean estimation problem, we show that heterogeneous users can have significantly different contributions to the overall utility, and that a fair incentive, according to our second notion, must take into account the amount of data, privacy level as well as the degree of heterogeneity. We formulate and solve the fairness-constrained mechanism design problem in this federated mean estimation problem, and also find that data heterogeneity and user properties play an important role in the solution.

While previous literature has investigated how platforms should design incentives for users in order to optimize its utility, the definitions of fairness we propose offers another important way to evaluate the fairness of these mechanisms. This is a critical step towards future research in ensuring that data acquisition mechanisms are both fair for users and efficient for platforms.

Though we provide a characterization of optimal fair mechanisms when privacy sensitivity is the same across users, designing mechanisms and developing theories that scale up these solutions to deal with platform that interact with large and diverse groups of users is critical. Additionally, users may come and go, as their sensitivities may change over time. Understanding how fluctuating users alter the model is of great practical significance. Furthermore, there is subjectivity in the choice of axioms, and other choices may lead to meaningful notions of fairness worthy of study. We have also assumed a non-divisible and transferable utility, but in many cases, users are paid for their data in the form of access to services. Investigating the impact of this will also be important for the practical application of a comprehensive theory for fairness.

∎

(83)

This establishes that the Nash equilibrium is cleanly separated into three regions. From this fact, we are able to show that the optimal strategy of the platform is also separated into three regions. Clearly, when privacy sensitivity is large, specifically, when c≥γm​a​x𝑐subscript𝛾𝑚𝑎𝑥c\geq\gamma_{max} then α∗=0superscript𝛼0\alpha^{*}=0 is the optimal solution, since p∗​(α)=1superscript𝑝𝛼1p^{*}(\alpha)=1 for all α<1𝛼1\alpha<1, and for α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 the objective becomes negative.

Alternatively, when c𝑐c is very small, we can determine the optimal value as follows. We first note that Assumption 1 implies that U​(p)𝑈𝑝U(p) is a decreasing function of p𝑝p. Thus the condition for α∗=cγm​i​nsuperscript𝛼𝑐subscript𝛾𝑚𝑖𝑛\alpha^{*}=\frac{c}{\gamma_{min}} is:

Thus we conclude, there are three regions:

Appendix C Monotonicity of Utility

When beginning this work, the dearth of algorithms that supported heterogeneous privacy constraints surprised us, given the increasing number of privacy options available to users. All of the algorithms that did exist were provably sub-optimal Hu & Gong (2020), or placed constraints on privacy parameters to prove approximate optimality Fallah et al. (2022). In both of these works, the pathology of the algorithm leads to error that is not monotonically decreasing in 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho}. For DP-based notions of privacy, which both of the aforementioned works are, one can prove that an optimal error must be monotonic. This observation inspired a recent work that studies a saturation phenomenon Chaudhuri & Courtade (2023). Similar ideas can also be found in Cummings et al. (2023). The idea is that an optimal algorithm will sometimes give users that choose a large ϵisubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖{\epsilon}_{i} more privacy than they asked for, to ensure that it still efficiently uses information from users j𝑗j with ϵj≪ϵimuch-less-thansubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑗subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑖{\epsilon}_{j}\ll{\epsilon}_{i}.

Appendix D Solving the Federated Mean Estimation Mechanism Design Problem

In this section we discuss how we produce Fig 7. Algorithm 1 describes the process. In the first step, we exploit the symmetry of the utility function by exploiting the fact that the utility does not change when ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} is exchanges between two users with the same nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}. This greatly reduces the number of payment functions that need to be calculated. Next, we compute the payment functions, again exploiting symmetry whenever possible to reduce calculations. Finally, for each partition, we efficiently search through the partition to see if there is a 𝝆𝝆\bm{\rho} that leads to a NE.

Comment on Fig 7

The observant reader will notice there is almost always one user with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1. This is an artifact of our model, where if only one user chooses ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1, it essentially behaves the same from a utility perspective as if it has chosen ρi=2subscript𝜌𝑖2\rho_{i}=2, but gets a reduced privacy sensitivity. It is possible to show that this means that other than the all zeros NE, there will always be one user with ρi=1subscript𝜌𝑖1\rho_{i}=1.

This same analysis can be applied to BR2​(𝐩;α)subscriptBR2𝐩𝛼\mathrm{BR}_{2}(\mathbf{p};\alpha). The NE is characterized by the sets where these two maps intersect. The following table summarize the equilibria p∗,q∗superscript𝑝superscript𝑞p^{*},q^{*}, written as scalars for readability.

When α𝛼\alpha is below the threshold for the two users (the top left entry), both c1subscript𝑐1c_{1} and c2subscript𝑐2c_{2} are too small for it to be worthwhile for the users to participate at the lower privacy option. Conversely, if α𝛼\alpha is above the threshold for both users, then both users choose the less private option. When neither of these extremes occur the results are more nuanced.
